width: 20em; margin: 0 auto;" |- ! style="background: #CCCCCC;" colspan="2" | Ice Hockey |- | '''First Meeting''' || BC 3, BU 1 (February 6, 1918) |- | '''Last Meeting''' || BU 5, BC 0 (November 13, 2011) |- | '''Games Played''' || 255 |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''All-time series''' || BU leads 126-112-17 |- ! style="background: #CCCCCC;" colspan="2" | Football (discontinued) |- | '''First Meeting''' || November 24, 1893 |- | '''Games Played''' || 32 |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | '''All-time series''' || BC leads 27-4-1 |} The '''Green Line Rivalry''', also known as the '''B-Line Rivalry'''<ref>[http://www.dailyfreepress.com/news/2002/09/16/Sports/Mens-Tennis.Has.Tough.Time.At.Bc.Invitational-274549.shtml Men's tennis has tough time at BC Invitational - Sports<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> <ref>[http://www.bcheights.com/news/2006/03/20/Sports/Terriers.Take.Hockey.East.Title.In.Ot-1690409.shtml Terriers take Hockey East title in OT - Sports<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>, the '''Battle of Boston'''<ref>[http://www.ncaasports.com/icehockey/mens/story/10510056 Battle of Boston ends in sweep - NCAA.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and '''Battle of Commonwealth Avenue'''<ref>[http://www.thehoot.net/?module=displaystory&story_id=718&edition_id=6&format=html The Brandeis Hoot<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>, is the name for the [[sports rivalry]] between [[Boston College]] and [[Boston University]]. <ref>{{cite news| url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/217128111.html?dids=217128111:217128111&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Oct+20%2C+2002&author=John+Connolly&pub=Boston+Herald&edition=&startpage=B.19&desc=COLLEGE+HOCKEY | work=Boston Herald | title=COLLEGE HOCKEY; FACEOFF 2002-03; Hockey East preview; A crowded house | first=John | last=Connolly | date=October 20, 2002}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.uscho.com/recaps/20082009/m/01/17/bc-bu.php | title = Advantage Terriers: Power Play Leads No. 2 BU Over No. 12 BC, 5-2 | work = USCHO.com | publisher = U.S. College Hockey Online | author = Scott Weighart | date = 2008-01-17 | accessdate = 2008-01-18}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web| url = http://pressherald.mainetoday.com/blogs/fromthepoint/037948.html | title = Green Line Rivalry to the Green Monster | work = pressherald.com | publisher = Portland Press Herald Maine Sunday Telegram | author = Rachel Lenzi | date = 2008-01-06 | accessdate = 2008-01-18}}</ref> The rivalry is named after the [[Green Line (MBTA)|trolley line]] that runs along [[Commonwealth Avenue]] and links the two schools as part of the [[MBTA]], [[Boston]]'s subway system. The two campuses lie less than five miles apart.
The Green Line Rivalry is considered one of the top rivalries in college sports <ref>{{cite news | title = Presenting the Nation's Top Ten Rivalries | publisher = ''The Miami Student'' |date=November 10, 2006 | url = http://www.miamistudent.net/media/storage/paper776/news/2006/11/10/Sports/Presenting.Nations.Top.10.Rivalries-2451882-page2.shtml}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news | title = Rivalry Renewed | publisher = ''The Concord Monitor'' |date=November 30, 2007 | url = http://www.concordmonitor.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071130/SPORTS/711300314#rivalry}}</ref> and first among college hockey rivalries.<ref>{{cite news | title = College Hockey's Top 10 Rivalries | publisher = ''College Hockey News'' |date=February 8, 2006 | url = http://www.collegehockeynews.com/news/2006/02/08_college.php}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news | title = BC-BU Rivalry Hits the Ice Friday Night | publisher = New England Sports Network (NESN) |date=November 30, 2007 | url = http://multimedia.boston.com/pub/m/1567450/bu_bc_rivalry_hits_the_ice_friday.htm?col=en-vid-pod_boston-ep&q=nesn&match=query,channel}}</ref> In 2005, ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' went as far as calling it "the greatest rivalry in all of sports."<ref>{{cite news | title = BU-BC? B-eautiful! | publisher = ''Sports Illustrated'' |date=January 24, 2005 | url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1109143/index.htm}}</ref>
==Ice hockey== ===History=== With 18 [[NCAA Men's Ice Hockey Championship|NCAA championship]] game appearances between them <ref>[http://www.ncaa.org/champadmin/champs_listing1.html Schools with the Most NCAA Championships<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>, including a matchup in the [[1978 NCAA Men's Division I Ice Hockey Tournament|1978 championship game]], Boston College and Boston University both field perennially competitive collegiate [[ice hockey]] teams and compete in the same league, [[Hockey East]], having both previously been members of the [[ECAC Hockey|ECAC]]. The two teams meet at least three times annually as part of their regular Hockey East season schedule and often also meet in the Hockey East and NCAA postseason tournaments. Additionally, each first and second Monday in February, BC and BU, along with [[Harvard University|Harvard]] and [[Northeastern University|Northeastern]], take part in the annual '''[[Beanpot (ice hockey)|Beanpot Tournament]]''' where the Eagles and Terriers usually square off in the championship game. BU has traditionally dominated the tournament, winning the title 29 times. The Eagles and Terriers last faced each other in the semifinals of the 2011 Beanpot, with BC edging BU 3-2 in overtime.
BC has won the [[NCAA Men's Ice Hockey Championship|national championship]] four times (1949, 2001, 2008, 2010); BU has won five times (1971, 1972, 1978, 1995, 2009). The two rivals faced off in the [[1978 NCAA Men's Division I Ice Hockey Tournament|1978 championship game]] in Providence, with BU claiming its third national championship with a 5-3 victory in [[Providence, RI]]. BU and BC have met in NCAA tournament play on one other occasion in the [[2006 NCAA Men's Division I Ice Hockey Tournament]] Northeast Regional Final, with the Eagles skating to a 5-0 victory over the top-seeded Terriers.
The rivalry is highlighted by its intensity and mutual contempt between both players and fans. For instance, after BU's victory over BC in the 1978 national championship, BU co-captain Jack O'Callahan was quoted as saying "We shouldn't have to beat BC for the nationals. Hell, we can do that anytime."<ref>[http://vault.sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1093490/2/index.htm It's still a one-way avenue. ]</ref> In a 2005 [[Sports Illustrated]] article, BC senior captain [[Ryan Shannon]] said that "Every once in a while, out in a restaurant, you see familiar faces. But hockey culture is so humble. Outside the rink, you see those guys as human beings," but when the on the rink: "They're evil. They're a Terrier."<ref>[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1109143/index.htm Bu-bc? B-eautiful!]</ref> Games feature an array of chants and insults chanted by each schools' students sections, the BC Superfans and the BU Dog Pound.
The rivalry was amplified when on January 8, 2010, BC and BU faced off at [[Fenway Park]], the first men's college hockey game to be played at Boston's iconic ballpark. BU edged BC 3-2 in front of a crowd of 38,000, the largest crowd to ever watch the two schools play.
The series dates to 1918, when BU first began playing hockey,<ref name=1918game>{{cite web| url = http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/bost/sports/m-hockey/auto_pdf/weekly-release.pdf | title = Oldest Terrier Rivalry | work = 2008-09 Menâs Ice Hockey Game Notes | publisher = Boston University Athletics | author = Brian Kelley | date = 2009-01-17 | accessdate = 2009-01-18}}</ref> and played its lone game that year against BC, a 3-1 loss at the [[Boston Arena]]<ref name=1918game/>. Since then, no other opponent has appeared on either teams' schedule more often<ref name=1918game/>. The schools have met 254 times; BU leads the series 125-112-17.
A documentary about the rivalry entitled ''The Battle of Comm Ave.'' was released in 2009 by Rival Films. The documentary contains game footage and interviews with numerous players and coaches.<ref>[http://slapshot.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/12/18/the-morning-skate-the-battle-of-comm-ave/ The Morning Skate: The Battle of Comm Ave]</ref>

==Football== "The Green Line Rivalry" originally referred to the [[American football|football]] rivalry between the schools, a series begun in 1893<ref name=football>{{cite web| url = http://cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/div_ia/acc/boston_college/opponents_records.php?teamid=372 | title = Boston College vs Boston University | work = cfdatawarehouse.com | publisher = College Football Data Warehouse | author = David DeLassus | accessdate = 2009-01-18}}</ref> and played annually from 1928-1942 and 1954-1962.<ref name=football/> With BC leading the series 27-4-1, BU discontinued the rivalry after the 1962 season.<ref name=football/> BU eventually terminated its football program in 1997.<ref>{{cite news| url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1571/is_n46_v13/ai_20083176 | title = Long on losses, short on funds, BU football lets clock run out | work = Insight on the News | publisher = News World Communications, Inc. | author = Gayle M.B. Hanson | date = 1997-12-15 | accessdate = 2009-01-18}}</ref>

==Other sports== The Green Line Rivalry has also come to refer to the rivalry between BC and BU in other sports.<ref>[http://www.dailyfreepress.com/media/paper87/news/2006/01/26/Sports/Rivalry.Rages.In.Pool.Bc.Wins-1513765.shtml The Daily Free Press<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In soccer, the two schools regularly open the season against each other with the expectation of large freshman-filled crowds.<ref>{{cite news | title = BU-BC Back in Swing: Green Line Rivalry resumes Saturday | publisher = ''Soccer New England'' magazine |date=August 31, 2007 | url = http://www.soccernewengland.com/articles/view_article.php?id=2765/}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news | title = Ready for Primetime: Green Line Rivalry resumes tonight | publisher = ''BU Today'' |date=September 18, 2009 | url = http://www.bu.edu/today/sports/2009/09/17/bu-men-s-soccer-ready-prime-time}}</ref>
